overview: Designed specifically for a field experience at the Museum of Osteology (or the Perot Museum Hall of Life), this curriculum consists of 10 high-intensity, 20-minute rotational stations. Students utilize extensive skeletal collections to explore comparative anatomy, forensic anthropology, and evolutionary biology. Unlike a passive tour, this is a structured academic 'decathlon' where student groups rotate through specific exhibit zones to collect data, analyze skeletal adaptations, and solve biological riddles.
prerequisites: Completion of High School Biology I is recommended but not required. Familiarity with basic anatomical terms (cranium, pelvis, vertebrae) is helpful.

fieldTrips.name: Museum of Osteology
fieldTrips.location: Oklahoma City, OK (Accessible day trip from North Texas/Dallas Area)
fieldTrips.description: America's only skeleton museum, housing over 300 real skeletons and 400 skulls. The facility offers specific educational scavenger hunts and hands-on labs tailored to the stations in this curriculum.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: The curriculum is specifically mapped to the exhibits found here (Dermestid beetles, Giraffe neck, Whale placement). It provides the primary data source for the inquiry activities.

fieldTrips.name: Perot Museum of Nature and Science
fieldTrips.description: The T. Boone Pickens Life Then and Now Hall features extensive fossil and modern skeletal exhibits.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Serves as a local alternative for Dallas/Tarrant County grants unable to travel to OKC. Stations 1, 3, 5, 7, and 10 can be easily adapted to the Perot's collections.

activities.title: Station 1: The Dietary Detective (Dentition)
activities.description: Students analyze skull exhibits to classify animals as carnivores, herbivores, or omnivores based on dental formulas and tooth morphology (molars vs. canines).
learningObjectives: Correlate tooth shape with dietary function.
Identify dental formulas in mammalian skulls.
Predict an animal's diet based solely on skeletal evidence.
teks: §112.34. Biology (c)(12)(A): interpret relationships, including predation, parasitism, commensalism
§112.34. Biology (c)(7)(A): analyze and evaluate how evidence of common ancestry is provided by anatomical homologies

brief: Direct students to the 'Carnivores and Herbivores' wall.
Briefly explain the difference between shearing carnassials and grinding molars.
detailed: Explain that dental morphology is the most accurate predictor of diet in the absence of soft tissue.
Instruct groups to find one 'mystery skull' and hypothesize its diet based on the ratio of sharp teeth to flat teeth.

brief: Locate a skull with sharp, pointed canines.
Locate a skull with flat, broad molars.
detailed: Record the specimen name of the sharp-toothed skull.
Draw the teeth profile of the Black Bear and determine if it is a carnivore or omnivore based on your observations.
Hypothesize the diet of the mystery specimen.

trioCompliance.justification: Provides a structured, standards-aligned field experience that moves beyond passive observation to active analysis of biological exhibits.
cfrCitations: 34 CFR 645.11(b): Curriculum to include laboratory science
34 CFR 645.40: Allowable costs for field trips
edgarCitations: 2 CFR 200.405: Allocable costs for student learning

activities.title: Station 2: The 7-Cervical Constant
activities.description: A comparative counting challenge where students verify mammalian homology by counting neck vertebrae in extreme examples (Giraffe vs. Human vs. Mouse).
learningObjectives: Verify the mammalian constant of seven cervical vertebrae.
Contrast the size and density of vertebrae across species.
Discuss evolutionary constraints on skeletal geometry.
teks: §112.34. Biology (c)(7)(E): analyze and evaluate the relationship of natural selection to adaptation

brief: Position the group near the Giraffe skeleton.
Ask for predictions on neck bone count.
detailed: Guide students to count the vertebrae physically using the exhibit.
Explain the concept of 'evolutionary constraint'—why mammals are stuck with 7 cervical vertebrae regardless of neck length.

brief: Count the neck vertebrae on the Human skeleton.
Count the neck vertebrae on the Giraffe skeleton.
detailed: Compare the length of a single giraffe vertebra to your own neck.
Explain in your notes why both have the same number (7) despite the size difference.
Sketch the difference in bone density.

trioCompliance.justification: Reinforces core biological concepts of homology and classification through direct observation of rare specimens.

activities.title: Station 3: Locomotion & Limb Mechanics
activities.description: Students analyze the appendicular skeletons of varied species to categorize them by locomotion type: plantigrade (flat foot), digitigrade (toes), or unguligrade (hooves).
learningObjectives: Classify animals based on foot posture.
Analyze the mechanical advantage of elongated tarsals/metatarsals.
Connect skeletal structure to speed and stability.
teks: §112.39. Physics (c)(6)(D): demonstrate and apply the laws of conservation of energy and conservation of momentum

brief: Explain the three types of walking: Plantigrade, Digitigrade, Unguligrade.
Challenge students to identify examples.
detailed: Discuss how moving the pivot point (ankle) up the leg increases stride length and speed.
Ask students to locate the 'heel' on a horse or deer.

brief: Find a plantigrade skeleton (heel on ground).
Find a digitigrade skeleton (on toes).
detailed: Sketch the leg of the Deer. Label where the 'heel' bone is located.
Hypothesize which leg structure allows for the fastest running speed.
Classify the human skeleton's walking style.

trioCompliance.justification: Connects biology concepts with physics (biomechanics) and veterinary science, suitable for UBMS rigor.
heaRequirements: Section 402E(b): Instruction in mathematics and science

activities.title: Station 4: The Dermestid Beetle Lab
activities.description: An observation station focusing on the museum's cleaning process. Students view the Dermestid beetle colony (if visible) or the prep-lab window to understand osteological preparation.
learningObjectives: Describe the life cycle of Dermestid beetles.
Explain why biological cleaning is preferred over chemical cleaning for bones.
Understand the role of decomposers in an ecosystem.
teks: §112.34. Biology (c)(12)(E): describe the flow of matter through... decomposers
§130.295. Forensic Science (c)(6)(F): differentiate between natural and artificial preservation

brief: Lead students to the beetle viewing area.
Discuss bleach vs. beetles.
detailed: Explain that chemicals damage DNA and bone integrity.
Ask students to identify larvae vs adults in the colony.
Discuss the time scale required for cleaning a skull.

brief: Observe the tank containing the Dermestid beetles.
Identify and draw a larva and an adult beetle.
detailed: Read the display to find out how long it takes a colony to clean a deer skull.
List two reasons why museums use beetles instead of boiling water.
Explain the role of these beetles in the wild.

trioCompliance.justification: Provides career exposure to niche STEM fields (entomology, museum curation) rarely seen in standard classrooms.

activities.title: Station 5: Flight Mechanics (Avian vs. Chiroptera)
activities.description: A comparative anatomy station contrasting the bird skeleton (keel bone, fused vertebrae) with the bat skeleton (elongated phalanges) to study powered flight.
learningObjectives: Contrast the skeletal structure of bird wings vs. bat wings.
Identify the 'keel' (sternum) and explain its function for muscle attachment.
Discuss convergent evolution in flight mechanics.
teks: §112.34. Biology (c)(7)(B): analyze results of natural selection
§112.39. Physics (c)(4)(D): calculate the effect of forces on objects

brief: Locate large Bird and Bat exhibits.
Point out the keel bone on the bird.
detailed: Discuss the muscle mass required for flight and where it attaches.
Contrast the 'hand-wing' of the bat with the 'arm-wing' of the bird.

brief: Sketch the wing bones of the Bat.
Sketch the chest bone (sternum) of the Bird.
detailed: Color the bones in the bat wing that correspond to human fingers.
Explain why the bird's sternum is shaped like the keel of a boat.
Determine which animal uses a membrane vs. feathers for lift.

trioCompliance.justification: Links biological adaptation to physics concepts (aerodynamics and force generation), supporting the Math/Science rigor of UBMS.

activities.title: Station 6: The Forensic Sex Determination
activities.description: Students utilize human osteology replicas (or specific primate exhibits) to identify sexual dimorphism in the pelvis and skull.
learningObjectives: Identify key markers of biological sex on the skull (brow ridge, mastoid process).
Analyze the pelvic inlet and subpubic angle.
Apply forensic criteria to estimate sex of a specimen.
teks: §130.295. Forensic Science (c)(6)(B): identify the characteristics of the human skeleton to determine... sex

brief: Guide students to the human evolution/anatomy section.
Demonstrate estimating the subpubic angle.
detailed: Discuss the functional reason for pelvic dimorphism (childbirth).
Show how to identify the brow ridge and mastoid process on the skull.
Supervise respectful handling/observation of human remains.

brief: Observe the human pelvis exhibit.
Observe the skull brow ridge.
detailed: Determine if the subpubic angle is greater than or less than 90 degrees.
Is the brow ridge prominent or smooth?
Based on these two markers, hypothesize the biological sex of the skeleton.

trioCompliance.justification: Direct application of forensic science standards using professional-grade specimens not available in high schools.
edgarCitations: 2 CFR 200.405: Costs allocable to federal award

activities.title: Station 7: Aquatic Adaptation (The Whale's Hand)
activities.description: An investigation of the Cetacean (whale/dolphin) skeletons to find the vestigial pelvis and analyze the homologous structure of the flipper.
learningObjectives: Identify homologous bones (humerus, radius, ulna) in a whale flipper.
Locate vestigial structures (pelvic remnants) in marine mammals.
Discuss the transition from land to sea.
teks: §112.34. Biology (c)(7)(A): analyze... homologies, including anatomical... and developmental

brief: Take students to the hanging whale/dolphin skeletons.
Challenge them to count the 'finger' bones.
detailed: Explain homology: same structure, different function.
Point out the vestigial pelvis bones 'floating' near the tail.
Discuss the evolutionary path of cetaceans from land mammals.

brief: Stand beneath the whale flipper.
Search for 'floating' bones near the tail.
detailed: Draw the flipper bones and label the Humerus, Radius, and Ulna.
Explain what these floating bones used to be when the whale's ancestors walked on land.
Why are these bones not attached to the spine?

trioCompliance.justification: Visualizing macro-evolutionary concepts through large-scale exhibits facilitates deep understanding of state biology standards.

activities.title: Station 8: Primate Comparison (Hands & Spines)
activities.description: Students compare human skeletons with other primates (Chimps, Orangutans) to note differences in spinal curvature (bipedalism) and hand proportions.
learningObjectives: Contrast the C-shaped spine of apes with the S-shaped spine of humans.
Compare the length of the thumb relative to the fingers in primates.
Relate skeletal structure to tool use and walking upright.

brief: Have students stand next to Chimpanzee and Human skeletons.
Point out Lumbar Lordosis (lower back curve) in humans.
detailed: Discuss how the S-curve acts as a spring/shock absorber for bipedalism.
Have students simulate the 'opposable thumb' grip vs. a hook grip.

brief: Observe the spine of the Chimpanzee and the Human.
Compare the hands.
detailed: Sketch the side-view curve of both spines.
Which species has a longer thumb relative to the hand size?
Hypothesize how the thumb length affects the ability to text on a phone or hold a pencil.

trioCompliance.justification: Engages students in comparative anthropology, a key component of advanced biology curricula.

activities.title: Station 9: The Ribcage Riddle (Snakes vs. Turtles)
activities.description: A contrast of extreme adaptations in the axial skeleton. Students compare the massive rib count of snakes to the fused rib-shell structure of turtles.
learningObjectives: Understand how ribs can be modified for protection (turtles) or locomotion (snakes).
Identify the relationship between the spine and the shell in Testudines.
Observe the ball-and-socket nature of snake vertebrae.
teks: §112.34. Biology (c)(11)(A): describe the role of internal feedback mechanisms

brief: Direct students to the reptile section.
Debunk the myth that turtles can 'crawl out' of their shells.
detailed: Explain that the turtle shell IS the ribs and spine fused together.
Discuss rectilinear locomotion in snakes (walking on ribs).

brief: Look inside the Turtle shell exhibit.
Observe the rib count on the Python.
detailed: Can you see the backbone fused to the top of the shell?
Count the approximate number of ribs on a 10cm section of the Snake.
Calculate an estimate of how many total ribs the snake has based on its length.
Explain how the snake uses its ribs to move.

trioCompliance.justification: Explores vertebrate diversity and specialized adaptations, aligning with state biology standards.

activities.title: Station 10: Pathology Hunt (Injuries & Disease)
activities.description: The final challenge requires students to find bones showing evidence of 'life history': healed fractures, arthritis, or dental abscesses.
learningObjectives: Distinguish between healthy bone and pathological bone.
Identify signs of bone remodeling (callus formation) after a fracture.
Discuss how skeletal analysis tells the story of an animal's life.
teks: §130.295. Forensic Science (c)(14)(A): distinguish between antemortem, perimortem, and postmortem injuries

brief: Explain the scavenger hunt rules.
Define 'Callus' (healed break) and 'Abscess' (infection).
detailed: Encourage students to look for asymmetry in skeletons (one thick bone, one thin).
Discuss bone remodeling and how the body heals itself.

brief: Find a bone that was broken and healed.
Find a skull with bad teeth.
detailed: Sketch the 'bump' (callus) on the healed fracture.
Find a skeleton showing signs of Arthritis (bumpy, rough joints).
Choose one specimen and write a 2-sentence 'biography' of its pain or injuries.

trioCompliance.justification: High-level inquiry activity requiring observation, hypothesis testing, and application of medical concepts.
